name: React
definition: React  is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It's widely used for single-page applications and has various concepts that make it unique.

name: Components
definition: Components are the building blocks of a React application. They define the visual and behavioral parts of the UI and can be reused throughout the application.

name: Props
definition: Props (short for properties) are a way to pass data from parent to child components. They are read-only and help to make the component reusable.

name: State
definition: State is a way for components to maintain data that can change over time and re-render when it does.

name: Lifecycle Methods
definition: Lifecycle methods are special methods that automatically get called as your component achieves certain milestones.

name: Hooks
definition: Hooks are functions that let you use state and other React features without writing a class. Examples include `useState`, `useEffect`, and `useContext`.

name: JSX
definition: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code within your JavaScript code. It's used to define and describe the structure of UI components.

name: Virtual DOM
definition: Virtual DOM is a lightweight in-memory representation of the actual DOM elements. React uses it to achieve fast updates and renders by diffing changes and updating only what's necessary in the real DOM.

name: Context
definition: Context provides a way to share values like configuration data, themes, and cached data between components without having to explicitly pass them via props.

name: Redux
definition: Though not part of the React core, Redux is a popular library used with React for state management. It provides a centralized store for state and allows components to dispatch actions and subscribe to changes.

name: React Router
definition: Also not part of React core, React Router is a popular library for adding navigation capabilities into your React application. It allows you to define routes and render different components based on the current URL.
